titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Office of Reports, Office Files of Richard Magat
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Office of Reports, Office Files of Richard Magat FA690

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-09-28 00:00:28 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Office of Reports, Office Files of Richard Magat

physdesc.extent: 3 record storage boxes, 4 LTR size Hollinger boxes, and 3 LGL size Hollinger boxes

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Level 1 Minimal Processing has been conducted to establish basic intellectual and physical control of the material and assess immediate preservation and conservation needs. Material remains as received, in original folders and storage boxes.
Level 3 processsing was completed for the 2018:061 accession of Richard Magat office files. This material was processed by Darren Young in September 2018.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details. Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

An additional group of Richard Magat office files was transferred to the RAC by the Ford Foundation in 2018 and was ingested by the RAC as Accession 2018:061. This accession was incorporated into the collection during processing in 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in 4 series by file type.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence, memoranda, publications and subject files.

Collection consists of more than one accession of Richard Magat office files ingested by the RAC over the years. An accession processed in 2018 consisted of a group of subject files regarding different press, publications, and public relations topics and was added to the end of the Subject Files series in order to reconstitute the relationship between the materials.

The RAC holds another Ford Foundation, Office of Reports, Office Files of Richard Magat collection. A more deliberate collection arrangement appears to have been imposed on this set of material during processing. Therefore, it was decided not to integrate the 2018 accession with that collection or to merge the two collections together. The finding aid for FA728 of Ford Foundation, Office of Reports, Office Files of Richard Magat can be accessed here .

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Richard Magat was a member of the Ford Foundation staff from 1957 until 1982. Throughout his career at the Foundation Mr. Magat worked in the Office of Reports. He held the following positions:

As Director and Editor, Mr. Magat was responsible for: preparing press releases, writing notes to editors and drafting letters to congressmen; writing and editing Foundation publications and articles including the Annual Report, Current Interests, and Ford Foundation Letter; recommending public reports on Foundation activity; responding to media inquiries and arranging press conferences; and administering the Office of Reports.
Mr. Magat also held the following positions:
1947-51, Dayton Daily News, Ohio, The Binghamton Sun, New York, Reporter
1951-52, McGraw-Hill Book Company, Editor in Technical Writing Service
1953-57, New York University, Senior News Writer, Office of Information Services
1967, Mayor's Advisory Panel on Decentralization of NYC Schools, Special Assistant
1975, Joint Committee for the Reappraisal of the Role of the Red Cross, Editor
1979, SUNY (New York) Fashion Institute of Technology, Instructor

Mr. Magat was born January 1, 1927. He received his A.B. degree in 1947 from New York University. Mr. Magat took additional courses at Columbia University, New York University and the New School. Mr. Magat is the author of Ford Foundation at Work, New York: Plenum (1979), and As Others See Us, Geneva: Henry Dumant Institute (1975). He also wrote articles for Saturday Review, Consumer Reports, Trans-action and other magazines and journals. Mr. Magat left the Ford Foundation in September 1982 to become President of the Edward W. Hazen Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains subject files Richard Magat created and maintained to document the Office of Report's work with various press, publications, and public relations projects and issues.
The most prevalent material formats found within the series are press clippings, correspondence, pamphlets, reports, tables and charts, notes, and publication mock-ups.
